questions.text:
Choose the correct statements about 2020 ACLS recommendations for adults.
  1. Double sequential defibrillation for refractory shockable rhythm is recommended in all cases
  2. Airway management should be prioritized during resuscitation from cardiac arrest in pregnancy
  3. Providers should always try one attempt at IV access before establishing IO access
  4. Audiovisual aids are recommended to ensure optimum CPR performance
  5. For cardiac arrest with a non-shockable rhythm, epinephrine should be administered only after 2 mins of CPR
questions.solution:
The 2020 AHA guidelines recommend the following about adult cardiopulmonary resuscitation:

  • Double sequential defibrillation for refractory shockable rhythm is not recommended in all cases usefulness has not been established.
  • Airway management should be prioritized during resuscitation from cardiac arrest in pregnancy as pregnant patients are more prone to hypoxia.
  • Providers should always try one attempt at IV access before establishing IO access as the IV route is associated with better clinical outcomes. Although IV access is preferred, for situations in which IV access is difficult, IO access is still considered a reasonable option.
  • Audiovisual aids are recommended to ensure optimum CPR performance as it has been found to be associated with better outcomes
  • For cardiac arrest with non-shockable rhythms, it is reasonable to administer epinephrine as soon as possible. For cardiac arrest with shockable rhythms, epinephrine should be administered after initial defibrillation attempts have failed
  • Laypersons may initiate CPR for presumed cardiac arrest as the risk of harm to the patient not in cardiac arrest is low even if they receive chest compressions
  • Physiological parameters such as arterial blood gas pressure of ETCO2 may be used to monitor and optimize CPR quality
  • Cardiac arrest survivors should have a multimodal rehabilitation assessment and treatment of physical, cardiopulmonary, cognitive, and neurological impairments before discharge from the hospital
  • Debriefings and referral for follow up and emotional support for all those involved in resuscitation may be beneficial

questions.text: An elderly man with hepatocellular carcinoma is scheduled to undergo a left hepatectomy. Which of the following Couinaud's liver segments will be removed during this procedure?
questions.solution:
The surgical term left hepatectomy corresponds to the removal of Couinaud segments 2, 3, and 4.

The Couinaud classification is a system used to categorize the liver into two primary functional lobes: the left and right lobes. The lobes are further divided into eight functional segments, based on hepatic portal venous branches. Each of these segments is supported by a biliary triad comprising branches from the hepatic artery, portal vein, and bile duct. 

The given image shows Couinauds segments corresponding to various procedures:

Other options:

Option A - Segments 6, 7 correspond to right posterior sectionectomy.

Option B - Segments 5, 6, 7, 8 corresponds to right hepatectomy or right hemihepatectomy.

Option C - Segments 2, 3 corresponds to left lateral sectionectomy.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: A female patient presents to the OPD with redness of the eye. The examination findings of her eye are shown in the image below. She had been previously diagnosed with glaucoma and was receiving a topical drug. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image in the above clinical scenario shows conjunctival hyperemia. It is the side effect of apraclonidine. It occurs due to an allergic response to apraclonidine. 

Apraclonidine is an alpha-adrenergic agonist. It is used in the treatment of ocular hypertension and glaucoma. It is available as a topical preparation of 0.5 and 1% solutions.

The notable side effects of apraclonidine include conjunctival hyperemia, sleepiness, and dry mouth. 

Prostaglandin analogs like latanoprost and bimatoprost can also be associated with conjunctival hyperemia.

Other options:

Option A: Pilocarpine is associated with side effects that include corneal edema, miosis, induced myopia associated with decreased vision, brow ache, and retinal detachment

Option B: Timolol is associated with exacerbation of respiratory conditions like asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bradycardia, depression, and impotence.

Option C: Echothiophate is associated with retinal detachment, miosis, cataract, pupillary block, glaucoma, iris cysts, brow ache, and punctal stenosis, which may further result in epiphora.

Related Pearl: Important adverse effects of anti-glaucoma drugs

Anti-glaucoma drug The adverse effects
Beta-blockers

Corneal hypoesthesia

Systemic side effects
Sympathomimetics

Lid retraction

CNS depression and apnea in infants and children (<2 years)
Prostaglandin analogs

Eyelash hypertrichosis

Macular edema

Iris pigmentation (Heterochromia iridis)

Peri-orbital fat depletion
Miotics

Retinal detachment

Cataract
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Systemic side effects

Corneal edema

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: An intern placed an intercostal drainage tube in a patient. Which of the following steps is incorrect?

choices.text: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury

questions.solution:
An intercostal tube (ICD) is placed along the upper border of the lower rib at the 5th intercostal space (ICS) to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle. Hence, option B is incorrect.

Chest tube insertion (thoracostomy) is indicated in pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, and pleural effusion in order to drain air/fluid from the pleural space.

The triangle of safety, usually in the 5th intercostal space, is the safest site for chest tube insertion, it is bound by:

  1. anterior to the midaxillary line
  2. above the horizontal line marked by the level of the nipple
  3. below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle

Contraindications include pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and diaphragmatic hernia.

Complications of this procedure:

  1. Infection at the site of insertion
  2. Unintentional injury to the lung - hemothorax
  3. Intercostal nerve/ vessel injury
  4. Subcutaneous hematoma/ emphysema

questions.text: You are a part of a project that involves the quality improvement of patient care in the hospital. The plan of the project is given below. What is the duration of the critical pathway in the project?
questions.solution:
The critical pathway would take 11 days in the given project plan. 

The critical path is the longest path in the network analysis. Any delay in the critical path will delay the entire project. Here, the longest pathway consists of "Start---> task B---> task C---> Finish," which is (5+6) 11 days.

Although task D is the longest activity taking 7 days, it is not the longest pathway.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old lady presented to you with purplish, itchy bumps on her shins along with findings in the buccal mucosa as shown. Which of the following drugs are used as first-line treatment for this condition?
  1. Clobetasol propionate ointment
  2. Topical cyclosporin
  3. Betamethasone soluble tablets     
  4. Topical PUVA cream
  5. Oral prednisolone
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with an image showing lacy white streaks in the buccal mucosa, suggests oral lichen planus. Clobetasol propionate ointment, soluble betamethasone tablets, and oral prednisolone (1, 3, and 5) are first-line drugs for treating oral lichen planus. 

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory skin disease that affects the skin and mucosa. It usually follows a chronic course with periods of relapse and remission.

The most common presentation of lichen planus on the skin is a patch of itchy, firm, purple-red-colored, flat-topped papules with lacy white lines on the surface known as Wickham's striae. This description is known as the characteristic "6 Ps" of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

On the buccal mucosa, the lesions are characteristically thin white reticular streaks, while on the tongue, they are seen as fixed white plaques.

Treatment of oral lichen planus:

  • First Line
    • Clobetasol propionate ointment 
    • Soluble prednisolone tablets, 5 mg in 15 mL water for mouthwash 
    • Betamethasone soluble tablets in water for mouthwash
    • Oral prednisolone for severe erosive lichen planus
  • Second Line
    • Topical retinoids like retinoic acid or isotretinoin
    • Oral prednisolone
  • Third line
    • Cortico-dependent or cortico-resistant erosive LP: systemic immunosuppressive agents like azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, methotrexate, cyclosporin, and topical ciclosporin.

 

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image: Trachyonychia

Related Pearl: Papulosquamous Disorders

  • Lichen planus
  • Psoriasis
  • Parapsoriasis
  • Pityriasis rubra pilaris
  • Pityriasis rosea
  • Seborrheic dermatitis
  • Secondary Syphilis
  • Drug Reactions
  • Reiter’s disease
  • Eczema
  • Neoplasms (Mycosis fungoides, Squamous cell carcinoma,  Bowen’s disease)
  • Tinea infections

questions.text: A pregnant lady with a gestation of 8 weeks comes to your clinic. While examining her, you notice she has severe acne. She tells you she has been taking oral medication and was advised to avoid excessive sun exposure while taking this drug. Which of the following is not a potential teratogenic effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
Oral medication for acne is likely to be isotretinoin. Macrognathia is not a potential teratogenic effect of isotretinoin.

Vitamin A derivatives(isotretinoin, acitretin) belong amongst the drugs with high teratogenic effects. They result in retinoic acid embryopathy by inhibiting neural crest cell migration during embryogenesis. This causes cranial neural crest defects involving the central nervous system, face, thymus, and heart. 

Specific anomalies include

  • Ventriculomegaly
  • Maldevelopment of the facial bones and cranium
  • Microtia or anotia
  • Micrognathia
  • Cleft palate
  • Conotruncal heart defects
  • Thymic aplasia or hypoplasia

Systemic retinoids are highly teratogenic and are absolutely contraindicated in pregnant women, those planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding mothers. Two negative pregnancy tests (on separate occasions) are required for females of childbearing age before starting acitretin or isotretinoin.

Baseline evaluation of serum lipids, transaminases, and CBC should be done before starting any systemic retinoids. These values should be checked monthly for the first 3–6 months and once every 3 months thereafter. Monthly pregnancy tests should be done while on the drug. Female patients should avoid conception for 3 years after discontinuing acitretin treatment for cutaneous psoriasis.

 

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
ACE inhibitors and ARBs

Hypoplasia of organs, anuria, irreversible renal failure
Carbimazole and Methimazole  

Choanal atresia, aplasia cutis, tracheoesophageal fistula and fetal goiter
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

Related Pearl: Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Image: Global Alliance Algorithm for Improving Outcomes in acne

BPO - Benzoyl peroxide

questions.text:
A 7-month-old child was brought by her mother with complaints of diarrhea and mucocutaneous lesions as shown in the image. The symptoms have been present since weaning was started. The mineral deficient in this child is a cofactor of many biological enzymes. Which of the below-listed enzymes use this essential mineral as its co-factor?
  1. Carbonic anhydrase II
  2. Carboxypeptidase A
  3. Alcohol dehydrogenase
  4. Adenosine deaminase
  5. Galactosyl transferase
questions.solution:
A child with eczematous rash typically in the perioral and perineal region and diarrhea is characteristic of acrodermatitis enteropathica which is due to secondary zinc deficiency. Zinc is an important co-factor for enzymes 1, 2, 3, and 4.

Zinc is a component of many metalloenzymes including:

  • Carbonic anhydrase II
  • Carboxypeptidase A
  • Alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Adenosine deaminase
  • Alkaline phosphatase
  • Phospholipase C
  • Superoxide dismutase

Zinc also has antioxidant activity as extracellular superoxide dismutase is zinc-dependent.

 

Selenium is the co-factor for the de-iodinase enzyme. 

It is an autosomal recessive disorder seen in infants due to a defect in intestinal zinc-specific transporter – Human ZIP4 protein which causes an inability to absorb sufficient zinc from the diet. Oral zinc therapy is the preferred management. The genetic locus is on chromosome 8q24.3. It classically presents while weaning from breast milk to formula, which has lower zinc bioavailability than breast milk. The symptoms are perioral and perineal rashes, periungual dermatitis- Beau’s lines on nails, chronic diarrhea, and alopecia. Children commonly present with symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with characteristic crusting at the edges. The perioral eruption usually spares the upper lip, giving it a U‐shaped or horseshoe‐shaped appearance.

Investigations would reveal low serum zinc and paneth cell inclusion is seen in the intestinal mucosal biopsy. 

Treatment – Zinc – 50mg/day for infants, up to 150mg/day for children

Chronic zinc deficiency can cause stunted growth, decreased taste sensation(hypogeusia), impaired immune function and hypogonadism, and hypopigmented hair.

Remember Mnemonic: DEAL for Acrodermatitis enteropathica

D – Diarrhoea

E – Eczematous dermatitis

A - Alopecia

L – Lethargy

Related Pearl: Metals as cofactors and prosthetic groups in enzymes

Metal  Enzymes
Zinc
  • Carbonic anhydrase II
  • Carboxypeptidase A
  • Alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Alkaline phosphatase
  • ALA dehydratase
  • Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Adenosine deaminase
  • Phospholipase C
Selenium

 

  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • Thioredoxin reductase
  • De-iodinase
Magnesium
  • Phosphofructokinase
  • Hexokinase
  • Glucose -6-phosphatase
  • Mutase
  • Enolase
Copper
  • Cytosolic superoxide dismutase
  • Tyrosinase
  • Cyt c oxidase
  • Lysyl oxidase
  • Amino acid oxidase
Molybdenum
  • Dinitrogenase
  • Xanthine oxidase
  • Sulfite oxidase
Manganese
  • Mitochondrial superoxide dismutase
  • Enolase
  • Arginase
  • Hexokinase
  • Phosphofructokinase
  • Ribonucleotide reductase
Iron
  • Succinate Dehydrogenase
Calcium
  • Lipase
  • Lecithinase
Nickel
  •    Urease

questions.text:
A male patient was brought to the emergency room after a road traffic accident. He produces unrecognizable sounds only, opens his eyes only to a painful stimulus and his right pupil alone is unreactive to light. His posture on the bed is shown below. What is this patient's calculated GCS-P score?

GCS-P: Glasgow coma scale - pupils.
questions.solution:
The above patient has a GCS-P score of 6 which is calculated as follows.

The score for eye-opening - opens only to painful stimulus - 2
The score for verbal response - sounds only - 2
The score for motor response - decorticate posturing - 3
Pupillary score - one pupil non-reactive - 1

GCS-P score - 

It is the Glasgow Coma Scale score with the incorporation of pupillary function. The pupillary function was added so that the brainstem function is also represented by the score. 

The total score is calculated by adding the score for eye-opening, verbal, and motor responses and subtracting the pupil score from the sum.

Total score = 2 + 2 + 3 - 1 = 6

Decorticate posture:

  • The upper limbs are flexed, the lower limbs are extended with toes pointed slightly inward, and the head is extended.
  • Decorticate posturing is given a score of 3 in best motor response in Glasgow Coma Scale.

Decerebrate posture:

  • Here, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. The neck and head are extended. 
  • Decerebrate posture has a score of 2 in best motor response on the Glasgow Coma Scale.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is:
questions.solution:
Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is Bainbridge Reflex.

The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction. Thus, this reflex helps prevent damming of blood in the veins, atria, and pulmonary circulation.

Other options:

Option A: Bezold–Jarisch Reflex: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnoea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

Option C: Cushing Reflex: When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to Rostral Ventro-Lateral Medulla (RVLM) neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.

Option D: J Reflex: The stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) causes apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension.

A "reverse" Bainbridge reflex has been proposed to explain the decreases in heart rate observed under conditions in which venous return is reduced, such as during spinal and epidural anesthesia, controlled hypotension, and severe hemorrhage.

Physiology of blood pressure regulation is an important topic as it is being frequently asked in both AIIMS and NEET examination.

questions.text: A patient comes with a complaint of vertigo in a certain head position. She denies any ear fullness or hearing loss. A Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis and an Epley's maneuver is performed to treat her condition. The symptoms are relieved due to the repositioning of otoconial debris from?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with vertigo and a positive Dix-Hallpike test is suggestive of benign positional paroxysmal vertigo (BPPV). The otoconial debris are repositioned from the posterior semicircular canal to the utricle to relieve the symptoms of BPPV.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal. 

A positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. It is due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle. The patient complains of vertigo on moving or tilting the head to the affected side. In up to 90 percent of the patients, it can be relieved by administering a therapeutic Epley's maneuver on the affected side.

The Epley's maneuver consists of five positions:

  Head and neck Body position
Position 1 Head turned 45°  to lie down in a head-hanging position
Position 2 Head turned with
affected ear up		 -
Position 3 The whole body and head rotated away from the affected ear in a face-down position  
Position 4 Head still turned to unaffected side by 45° Brought to sitting position
Position 5 Head turned forward with chin brought down 20° -

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man has been bitten by a wild dog resulting in multiple, deep lacerated wounds on his leg left. He has a record of previous complete pre-exposure vaccination against rabies that he had taken 6 months back. He presents at the district hospital where you provide him with the appropriate management which should include:
  1. Washing wound with soap and water
  2. Giving Rabies vaccine booster day 0
  3. Rabies vaccine booster on day 3
  4. Apply povidone-iodine on the wound
  5. Rabies immunoglobulin on Day 0
questions.solution:
The patient in the scenario above has been bitten by a wild dog resulting in a category III wound and has a record of previous complete pre-exposure vaccination against rabies that he had taken 6 months back. For such a rabies-exposed person who has documentation of previous complete rabies vaccination(>3 months old), a booster dose of IM/ID vaccination is sufficient on days 0 and 3.

Rabies immunoglobulin is not indicated in such cases because an anamnestic response will follow the administration of a booster regardless of the pre-booster antibody titer.

Proper wound care is essential in all dog bite cases. Washing with soap and water followed by application of antiseptic agent (Any virucidal agent like povidone-iodine, alcohol, etc) is to be done.

 

Zero by 30 : is the Global strategic plan to end human death from dog mediated rabies by 2030.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient comes to the OPD with a fever. The fever is high-grade and started with a sudden onset 24 hours ago. He also complains of severe headache, retroorbital pain, and myalgias with nausea and vomiting. His appetite is reduced. On examination, his temperature is 100.4 F, pulse rate is 100 bpm and BP is 110/70 mm of Hg. There are multiple small vesicles on the hard palate. Which of the following is the least useful for diagnosing dengue fever in this patient if blood samples are drawn in this visit?

choices.text: Viral culture and isolation in aedes albopticus c6/36 cell line
ELISA for IgG antibody against dengue virus

questions.solution:
On day 2 of presentation, ELISA for IgG antibody against dengue virus is not advised.

This patient's presentation of fever with myalgias (break-bone fever), retroorbital pain, headache, and palatal vesicles are all seen in Dengue fever. There might be a transient macular rash and cervical lymphadenopathy on day 1. A maculopapular rash beginning in the trunk and spreading to the extremities and face may be seen around the time of defervescence (3-5 days).

Dengue fever is caused by the Dengue viruses 1-4 belonging to the genus Flavivirus transmitted by the bite of the Aedes mosquito. ELISA against Dengue antibodies can detect IgM and IgG separately. IgM appears early by 3-5 days of fever (can persist up to 90 days), followed by the appearance of IgG by the end of one week and peaking around 14-21 days of illness.

However, this patient has symptoms for less than 2 days and IgM ELISA might give a false negative result. Further, the IgG ELISA may give a false-positive result due to cross-reactivity of the  Dengue viruses with other members of the Flavivirus genus.

NS1 antigen is a non-structural viral protein antigen that is detectable from day one of fever. It is highly specific for dengue.

Dengue virus can be detected from blood one day before the onset of symptoms by viral culture after inoculation into mosquito cell line or detection of specific genes of viral RNA by real-time RT-PCR.

questions.text:
A patient has been bitten by a snake, and the relatives have brought the snake with them. Which of the following findings will assure you that the snake is non-poisonous?
  1. Short, solid fangs
  2. Conspicuous pit between eye and nostril
  3. Small head scales
  4. Belly scales that do not cover the entire breadth
  5. Bite showing a number of small teeth marks in a row
questions.solution:
Solid and short fangs, incomplete belly scales that do not cover the entire breadth, and bite wound showing a number of small teeth marks in a row are usually seen with non-poisonous snakes.

A conspicuous pit between the eye and nostril is mostly seen in pit vipers, which are poisonous. Other features of poisonous snakes include small head scales, large belly scales that cover the entire belly, and long and canalized fangs.

Related Pearl: Difference between Poisonous and Non- Poisonous Snakes

 

Poisonous snake

Non poisonous snake

Belly scales

Large and it covers the entire belly

Small and do not cover the entire belly

Head scales

Small

Large

Fang

Long and canalised

Short and solid

Tail

Compressed

Not markedly compressed

Habits

Nocturnal

Not so

Bite

Two fang marks

A number of small teeth marks in a row

questions.text: Identify the following.

choices.text: A- Cancellous screw; B - Malleolar screw; C - Cortical screw
A- Malleolar screw; B - Cancellous screw; C - Cortical screw
A- Malleolar screw; B - Cortical screw; C - Cancellous screw
A- Cancellous screw; B - Cortical screw; C - Malleolar screw

questions.solution:
In the given image: 

  • A represents a malleolar screw
  • B represents a cortical screw
  • C represents a cancellous screw

Identification features of the screws are as follows:

Malleolar screw: Modified cancellous screw with a sharp-pointed tip. It can be inserted without pre-drilling. These screws are used for internal fixation of malleolar fractures.

 

Cancellous screw: Larger thread, high pitch, compression by partial threading with a blunt tip. The larger threads provide for more purchase in the soft cancellous bone. 

 

Cortical screw: Smaller thread, low pitch, compression produced by over drilling proximal cortex. The whole length of these screws is threaded and has a diameter of 2–4.5 mm. It functions as a positional screw or a lag screw for interfragmentary compression.

 

Most orthopedic implants are made of titanium-based alloys because they are highly resistant to corrosion.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the casualty after a minor accident that occurred when he failed to see a bike coming from sideways. His mother says he is a clumsy child, who sometimes knocks things over accidentally even at home. Visual field examination findings are given below. On imaging, an intracranial mass is seen. The resected specimen shows cholesterol-rich machinery-oil-like fluid. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Patients with adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma present with bitemporal hemianopia (image), and the cystic component of this tumor contains a cholesterol-rich, thick, brownish-yellow fluid that is comparable to "machine oil."

Craniopharyngiomas develop from remnants of the Rathke pouch. Adamantinomatous variant of craniopharyngioma predominates in childhood.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur in the suprasellar region. Patients usually present with headache and visual field abnormalities. These children also have endocrinological abnormalities such as growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to hypopituitarism (GH deficiency).

These tumors are minimally invasive, adhere to the adjacent brain parenchyma, and engulf normal brain structures. CT may show calcifications associated with the solid and cystic components.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the clinic for evaluation for recurrent hemiparesis. The child has also had two episodes of seizures in the last six months. On examination, the child is short-statured. There is associated motor weakness. Laboratory examination shows lactic acidosis, and muscle biopsy appears as shown below with Gomori trichrome stain. What is the likely mode of inheritance of this disorder?
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex is suggestive of mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS). The patient presents in childhood, with classical features of hemiparesis and hemianopia, suggestive of stroke-like episodes. The histopathology of the muscle biopsy stained with Gomori-trichrome stain shows ragged red fibers. This disease has a mitochondrial inheritance.
 
In mitochondrial inheritance, if the mother is affected and the father is normal, then all their children (both male and female) will be affected. However, children born to an affected father and a normal mother will not be affected.
 
The mitochondrial inheritance pattern is as shown in the image below:
The unique feature of mitochondrial inheritance is maternal inheritance, as the disease is transmitted through the affected mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which is derived from the maternal mitochondria.
 
The ovum contains several mitochondria, while the spermatozoa have very few mitochondria if present. Hence, the mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is entirely derived from the ovum.
 
Therefore, the affected mother transmits the disease to all the offsprings (both male and female), and only the daughters of the affected mother, will further transmit the disease.
 
Characteristic features of mitochondrial inheritance:
  • The mitochondrial DNA encodes enzymes required for oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, organs that are most dependent on oxidative phosphorylation are the ones most affected in diseases due to mutations in mtDNA. These organs include central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys.
  • There are several thousands of copies of mtDNA in each mitochondrion, of which only a few copies are affected in case of mutation. Therefore, a diseased individual possesses copies of both wild-type mtDNA and mutant mtDNA in each mitochondrion. This phenomenon is called heteroplasmy. 
  • The disease manifests if a minimum number of copies of mutant mtDNA are present in the mitochondria that can lead to oxidative dysfunction, called the threshold effect. In most cases, this threshold effect is reached in the organs as mentioned above.
  • Also, during a cell division, the wild and mutant copies of the mtDNA are unequally distributed among the daughter cells. As a result, the expression of the disease varies even among different cells of an organ.

Some other clinical features of this condition are - 

  • Cortical blindness
  • Focal and generalized seizures
  • Recurrent migraine-like episodes and vomiting
  • Short stature
  • Hearing loss
  • Muscle weakness
  • The stroke like episodes in MELAS are characteristic because they do not respect vascular territories

A replapsing-remiting course is most common with stroke-like episodes leading to progressive neurologic dysfunction and dementia.

questions.text: Which among the following demonstrates Water’s view?
questions.solution:
Image 1 demonstrates Waters' view.

Waters’ view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is taken such that the patient is erect and facing the detector with the chin raised. The orbitomeatal line should be at an angle of 37° from the receptor.

Structures seen in this view are:

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (if taken with the mouth open).
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Infratemporal fossa.

Indications:

  • Acute sinusitis
  • Facial fractures

Other options:

Image 2- Towne's view is an anteroposterior view with a 30° tilt from above and in front. The nuchal ridge should be touching the detector.

Image 3- Caldwell's view (Occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is taken with the nose and forehead touching the detector. The X-ray beam is projected 15–20° caudally.

Image 4- Schuller's view is a lateral oblique view of the mastoid. The sagittal plane of the skull should be parallel to the film. X-ray beam is projected cephalocaudal at 30° to the sagittal plane.

The image below shows an X-ray taken in Waters' view:

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of temporal bone

questions.text: A 42-year-old diabetic male has been in the post-operative surgery ward with a central line inserted for the past 8 days. He develops a high-grade fever, cough, confusion and his respiratory rate is 32/minute and BP is 100/70 mm Hg. Laboratory results show raised blood counts and 1,3 Beta D Glucan levels of ≥80 pg/mL. Which of the following organisms is not a likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
In the given diagnostic assay 1,3 beta D Glucan assay levels of ≥80 pg/mL is considered positive. Invasive cryptococcosis is not detected by this assay.  

The given scenario can be a case of invasive fungal infection (candida, aspergillus ) which can occur in post-operative cases through contaminated central lines.

1,3-β-d-glucan (BDG) is a cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi, more commonly in candida, aspergillus and pneumocystis jiroveci.  

However, it is not used in the diagnosis of cryptococci, the zygomycetes, and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.  

This assay is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect beta D Glucan by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. These cells contain components of the Limulus clotting cascade, including factors C and G, which initiate coagulation in the presence of bacterial liposaccharide and Beta D Glucan, respectively. By eliminating factor C from the lysate, the manufacturers limit activation of the cascade to BDG alone.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents for a health check-up, during which the doctor finds that he is reluctant to talk about his illnesses. He is suspicious that the information will be used to harm him. He does not trust his family either for the same reason. He does not forgive easily and bears grudges. What is the type of personality disorder that he has?
questions.solution:
The given history of long-standing suspiciousness, not trusting people, and bearing grudges for insults is suggestive of paranoid personality disorder.

Paranoid personality disorder, a part of cluster A personality disorders, is characterized by pervasive suspiciousness and mistrust in all interpersonal relationships. They are excessively fearful of perceived threats and deceit and often read hidden demeaning or threatening meanings into benign remarks. They are reluctant to confide in others due to the fear that the information they provide will be used against them maliciously.

They tend to be extremely jealous, hostile, argumentative, and defensive. Their paranoia prevents them from establishing any overly involved relationship. They persistently bear grudges and can get irritable and angry easily. They use the defense mechanism of projection by displacing their insecurities on others. 

They may not be willing to accept that they need psychiatric help. Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice. Care should be taken by the therapist to not behave defensively if accused of making a mistake. Pharmacotherapy is generally used to deal with anxiety and agitation. Diazepam is used as an anxiolytic, while antipsychotics like haloperidol or pimozide may be required to deal with agitation.

Other options:

Option A: Individuals with schizoid personality disorder are usually eccentric and isolated. They neither desire nor enjoy close relationships. They always choose to be alone and lack close friends. They are emotionally cold and appear indifferent to praise or criticism.

Option B: Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder appear odd and strange to surrounding people. They have ideas of reference, odd or magical thinking, inappropriate or constricted affect, and suspiciousness.

Option D: Individuals with histrionic personality disorder have excessive emotional and attention-seeking behaviour. They are uncomfortable in situations where they are not the centre of attraction. They also have inappropriate, sexually seductive, or provocative behaviour. They try to use their physical appearance to draw others' attention.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist
